Engineering Example

Here we shall find a formula for the curvature of a bent beam.

Example

When a horizontal beam is acted on by forces which bend it, each small segment of the beam will be slightly curved and can be regarded as an arc of a circle. The radius \(R\) of that circle is called the radius of curvature of the beam at the point concerned. If the shape of the beam is described by an equation of the form \(y = f(x)\) then there is a formula for the radius of curvature \(R\) which involves only the first and second derivatives \( \dfrac{dy}{dx}\) and \( \dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2}\).

The equation is found as follows.

Start with the equation of a circle in the simple implicit form \[x^2 + y^2 = R^2\] and perform implicit differentiation twice. Now use the result of the first implicit differentiation to find a simple expression for the quantity \(1+ \left( \dfrac{dy}{dx}\right)^2\) in terms of \(R\) and \(y\); this can then be used to simplify the result of the second differentiation, and will lead to a formula for \( \dfrac{1}{R}\) (called the curvature) in terms of \( \dfrac{dy}{dx}\) and \( \dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2}\).

Have a go before looking at the solution below.

Solution

Differentiating \( x^2 + y^2 = R^2\) gives \[ 2x + 2y\dfrac{dy}{dx} = 0. \hspace{5cm} (1)\] Differentiating again gives \[ 2 + 2 \left( \dfrac{dy}{dx} \right)^2 + 2y \dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2} = 0. \hspace{3cm} (2)\] From \( (1)\), \[ \dfrac{dy}{dx} = -\dfrac{x}{y} \hspace{0.5cm} \therefore \hspace{0.5cm} 1 + \left( \dfrac{dy}{dx} \right) ^2 = 1 + \dfrac{x^2}{y^2} = \dfrac{y^2 + x^2}{y^2} = \left( \dfrac{R}{y} \right)^2. \hspace{2cm} (3) \] So \[1 + \left( \dfrac{dy}{dx} \right)^2 = \left( \dfrac{R}{y} \right)^2.\] Thus \( (2) \) becomes \[ 2 \left( \dfrac{R}{y} \right)^2 + 2y \left( \dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2} \right) = 0 \hspace{0.5cm} \therefore \hspace{0.5cm} \dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2} = \dfrac{R^2}{y^3} = \left( \dfrac{1}{R} \right) \left( \dfrac{R}{y} \right) ^3 \] so \[ \dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2} = -\dfrac{1}{R} \left( \dfrac{R}{y} \right)^3. \hspace{4cm} (4) \] Rearranging \( (4) \) to make \( \dfrac{1}{R} \) the subject and substituting for \( \left( \dfrac{R}{y} \right) \) from \( (3) \) gives the result: \[ \dfrac{1}{R} = \dfrac{\dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2}}{ \left[ 1 + \left( \dfrac{dy}{dx} \right)^2 \right] ^{3/2}} \] The equation usually found in textbooks omits the minus sign but the sign indicates whether the circle is above or below the curve, as you will see by sketching a few examples. When the gradient is small (as for a slightly deflected horizontal beam), i.e. \( \dfrac{dy}{dx}\) is small, the denominator in the equation for \( (1/R)\) is close to \(1\), and so the second derivative alone is often used to estimate the radius of curvature in the theory of bending beams.
